Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2007 10:46AM cindiedee wrote: I can only tell you how they did it for my sister - they did the frozen section in the OR and said all ok - no cancer. A week later she returned to the doc for post op and removal of sutures - they informed her that she DID have breast cancer - so I have to think that the frozen section results don't really count - it is when the total pathology is done that they know for sure. Hope this helps!Cindie

Posts.Title: Insurance Coverage MarieL msannie57

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2007 10:50AM cindiedee wrote: Myriad Labs called me today and said my insurance co. said they would cover 90% and I would owe $312 which is the remaining 10%. I told them I had a $1000 per year maximum out of pocket and since I just had PBM/Recon, I had already reached that and she said ok, you don't owe anything and we will start your test today - should have results in 10 days. So, there you go! Sometimes you just have to give them more info than they have - I could have just paid the $312 but I knew I had already paid out $1100 on the PBM/Recon and had reached my max - so be sure and check it all out if they say you owe something towards the test.

Posts.Title: Just had stereotactic biopsy

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2007 11:46AM cindiedee wrote: Waiting to hear from you - praying for you as you go to your doc's appt. this afternoon. We will have to assume that everything isn't normal but - that does not mean you have BC - for everyone who was told they did and they didn't and for all those who were told they didn't and they did - ONLY a biopsy can be sure. I would also go to some other facility for sure if you insurance allows - and that rad. should not do your biopsy - he has no tact and Lord knows what he would tell you with a biopsy! Please post when you are able and let us know you are ok - no matter what the doc says to you - just about everyone here has been through this and we are with you - hugs and blessings, Cindie
Posts.Title: Well, looks like onto the next step gshoemate cindiedee

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2008 02:26PM cindiedee wrote: leener - I, and others on this site, had to do this- it is called a wound vac - usually used when an incision comes open for some reason.  I was on a wound vac all last summer - I had PBM/SGAP recon and one of my butt cheek incisions burst open.  I had to go the wound care clinic 3 times a week to have it changed out and it was literally, a PITA!  But, it did the trick - all the docs said that without it, my body would have taken a year or more to heal from the inside out.  So, if you need it, do it.  I also had to have PICC lines put in my arms so that I could have IV antibiotics at home while I was on the wound vac.  Make sure with your insurance co. that they cover this - mine was over $4000 a month just rental on the machine, plus the cost of supplies, meds, etc - I couldn't ever have afforded it without good insurance. Best of luck as you move forward - Cindie
Posts.Title: inserting a "vacuum" with sponges leener cindiedee

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2008 04:54PM cindiedee wrote: Sally - whoo hoo!  I know the feeling - I was an uninformed negative (which shocked the genetics counselor and me!) and I cried for 2 days after getting my results - I was (and am) just so damn grateful! Best wishes to you and you WILL get through all your treatments knowing you haven't passed the gene(s) on! Hugs, Cindie
Posts.Title: Finally some good news! mustangsally LUVmy2girlZ

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2007 04:26PM cindiedee wrote: Bunnysmama - no real details from the GC - just that I was negative and that "they" (at the cancer center) were shocked that I was negative given my family history (I am the ONLY female in my family without BC) - she did say she would be mailing me the official results on Monday for my files and that if I have any questions after receiving that, to please call her. Like I said, I couldn't breathe, couldn't think, etc - I just kept praying "let me be negative, let me be negative" - she could have told me the moon was made of cream cheese and I would have said "uh huh - ok" - I was just SO scared of what she was going to tell me - when I saw her the first time she said she would only give me the results in person,not over the phone - even if I was negative - so I was really shocked when she started the coversation with "Well we are all just shocked up here, given your pedigreed, that you are negative" - I was shocked that she told me! I was expecting her to tell me that she had my results and could I come for an appt. next week - and I was wondering how I would survive the weekend without knowing! As I said before and I will always say again, Thank you Lord............it is the only reason I am here today. Hugs to all, Cindie

Posts.Title: Excisional Breast Biospy lady4law lady4law

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2007 05:14PM cindiedee wrote: Lady Jean - sorry - not sure why I had it in my mind that tomorrow was your day. If there is a board for IBC, you can post all your info on that one - I haven't had IBC and only know a little about it. In the OR, they frequently do a frozen section - looking for BC - but they cannot be positive without the entire pathology. (My sister had a lumpectomy, they did the frozen section and came out and said "all clear and no cancer" - she went back to doc for a checkup about 10 days later and they sat her down and told her she had BC - so the frozen section may not be correct. The stages of BC are 1 through 4. I can't tell you what each one is specifically but I do know if your or anyone's cancer is Stage 4, that is the worst - usually means the cancer has already spread to other places in the body. I can only imagine how frightened you are this week - I will pray the week goes by very quickly for you and that you get some kind of answers. Many hugs, Cindie
Posts.Title: Excisional Breast Biospy lady4law lady4law

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2007 07:39PM cindiedee wrote: Lady Jean - Cindie here again - that really is an old wives tale - and it is really sad that people still believe it. With the needle biopsy, they can't always get what they need to determine BC - what kind, what stage, etc - and I am a HUGE believer of "the only good lump is the one in the jar" - get the excisional biopsy and the lump will be just cut out totally - that way the entire thing can be biopsied. And you no longer have that lump. If it is IBC then you/they will know and a treatment plan can be formed - whether it includes surgery/chemo/rads - at least you will have a plan. Still praying for you this coming week - that all goes well, the lump gets removed, and that you finally get the results you need. Gentle hugs coming your way.............Cindie
Posts.Title: Excisional Breast Biospy lady4law lady4law

Posts.Content: cindiedee wrote: Hey to all of you! Well, I knew my BRCA test results would be in this week - just did't know which day. Let me tell you - I have had the worst nightmares the past 3 nights - every single night - I will bet I haven't slept 2 hours any night this week - just had nightmares - that they told me I was positive for BOTH BRCA 1 and BRCA 2, that DH and I were sitting with the GC and she was telling him I was going to die from this and I was crying - just awful stuff - the past 3 days it is ALL I have thought of. Well the phone rang this afternoon (and we have caller ID) and DH says "it's the cancer center" and I just KNEW it was THE call. It was like I was paralyzed and couldn't breathe - after 4 rings I finally answered the phone but I could barely speak. Then the GC says "we are all shocked up here because of your pedigreed but you are NEGATIVE"!!!!!!!!!!!!! I absolutely could not breathe at all at that point. Finally I asked her a couple of questions ("are you POSTIVE that I am NEGAtIVE" etc) and hung up and started bawling - which DH was sure meant I was positive - OMG - I am so lucky today and thank you God. I immediately emailed my son (he was at work) and told him. If y'all remember, my daughter is HORRIFIED that I did PBM/recon and told me she NEVER wanted to know my BRCA testings status - so then I wondered if I should tell her or not. Well God answered that question for me - 5 minutes later my granddaughter called and we chatted about her day - 20 minutes later my daughter got on the phone and just hearing her voice started me bawling! So I told her I had a gift for her and I told her - she acted like it was no big deal - kind of like "well I don't have to worry about that then" and she changed the subject and started chatting! I have been bawling on and off the rest of the afternoon - with my family history, I just can't believe I am in the lucky 50% - thank you God! Hugs to all, Cindie Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2007 05:28PM cindiedee wrote: Hello ladies - I also am having troubles with dissolvable stitches - my body does not like them!  I had Stage II SGAP on Sept.  18th - all went well but in week 2, I developed 2 suture abcesses - very painful and I had to go back to SC and stay another week - PS had to cut them both open, clean them out, pack them daily, etc - we just got back today.  The incisions are still open - he opted not to suture them this time (thank you Lord) - he left them open to close on their own.  The funny part is I have partial sutures around the new areola/nipples - bright purple just sticking right out - I have tried to pull them out with tweezers but they are connected to something inside and are not about to come out.  The doc also did lipo and each "lipo hole" has a couple stitches in it too - and not any where close to coming out - they are in there tight.  I just had major problems with these dissolvable sutures - I even had to go to a doc here and have some removed because they were imbedded in my skin - this was prior to the abcesses.  Lordy I will be glad when this is all over! Hugs to all my suture sisters!  Cindie
Posts.Title: Spitting Stitches? amythol BRCABabe

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2007 10:38AM cindiedee wrote: Sandyk - I do think the nurse said mine were Vicryl also - and she did say some people's bodies reject any kind of sutures they use - I think my body must be one of them because with both surgeries I have had to go to a doc and have them removed because they were imbedded in my skin - and of course I am now sitting on a pile of pillows because of the abscesses I had on the butt from the sutures.  No more sutures for me - my body just won't tolerate them!

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2007 11:27AM cindiedee wrote: GMG - first of all, take a deep breath - now.......breathe in......breathe out.........repeat, repeat, repeat. Believe me, you came to the right place - and I understand your anger - I am of the "the only good lump is the one in the jar" school - get those lumps out and KNOW what you have - no guessing. I get sooooo angry sometimes with the medical profession - there are so many wonderful, caring docs out there........and then some ass who wants to give you antibiotics for a breast lump! Now I know you could have an infection in the ducts........but he didn't even find the second lump? Oh no - time to find a new doc! Glad you had all the immediate testing done - the waiting for the results is the worst part of it all - nothing they can say is as bad as what you are imagining! Hang in there - we are all here for you - please let us know what you find out - hugs and prayers coming your way. Cindie

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2007 04:54PM cindiedee wrote: OMG - what a crock!  Let me see, my mom had narrow hips and thighs (but a large abdomen), my sister has always had narrow hips and thighs (no abdomen and a nice bust line), and then there is me - I have WIDE hips -  way out of proportion to the rest of me, had no chest at all, little abdomen and let's see - Mom and sister had BC multiple times (Mom died from BC mets) and I had NO BC (thank you Lord) but was 98% positive on getting BC - so having a PBM/recon was a total nobrainer for me.  But it appears our family got it backwards - the skinny hipped ones got it and me with the wide hips didn't!  Every day there is something else about all this - what our body shape is, what diet we follow, family history etc - wonder if they will ever figure it all out so people can truly avoid BC - or any kind of cancer for that reason - Sheesh!  Cindie

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2008 12:09PM cindiedee wrote: Just an FYI - every doc I have seen has said this is just an old wives tale - doing a biopsy does not spread cancer.  If that were the case, the millions of women who have biopsies each year would have cancer spread throughout their bodies. I know what a nerve wracking time this is for you - remember that 80% of lumps are benign.  Prayers coming your way for B9 results! Cindie

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2007 09:27AM cindiedee wrote: KCSusan - hey - I had SGAP done May 30th and I had one butt incision dehisce and split open like you are talking about.  I ended up back in the hospital for a week on IV antibiotics and they put a wound vac on like you are getting.  I ended up having the wound vac for 8 weeks total - it is amazing how it heals you.  I had to go to a wound clinic 3 times a week to have it unpacked/repacked and it is painful - I ended up taking pain meds an hour before I went each time - it didn't take all the pain away but it did help.  The docs told me without the wound vac, it would have been a year or more to heal the incision - best of luck to you - it really will work!  Cindie

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2008 07:52PM cindiedee wrote: Annie - I had BRCA testing (in the US) - I paid $100 out of pocket to see the genetic counselor and she drew the blood.  The actual test cost $3120 - alot more than $200!  But I was fortunate, my insurance co. paid for the test. That being said, for your daughter's sake, I hope you do the test - if you are negative, then your daughter cannot have the BRCA1 or 2 mutated gene.  If you are positive, then your daughter has a 50/50 chance of also having the mutated gene.  Keep in mind one thing - every single doc I have seen about this has said that BRCA 1 and 2 are the only BC genes currentlly known to increase risk - but that there are probably another 100 BC genes out there that science just hasn't found and identified yet.  I am what is called an "uninformed negative" - meaning no one else in my family has (or will) test - but my great grandma and my mom both died from BC and my sister had BC 3 times before she had a double mastectomy at age 39.  Because of my family history and I also had so many biopsies and lumps removed, I decided to have a PBM with SGAP reconstruction - and I sleep so much better at night knowing I have done all that I can to reduce my risk and to "get it(BC)" "before it gets me".  I had already had a complete hysterectomy many years ago, so at least I didn't have to do that at the same time. My heart goes out to you being the first family "history" - and for your daughter having to go through all this at such a young age. Hugs and Blessings, Cindie
